prompt:
Human: Who was Oscar Wilde?

Assistant: Oscar Wilde (1854-1900) was an Irish playwright and novelist.  He became quite well known in Victorian England for his plays and novels, but in fact he was sent to prison for three years after a political trial due to his views about Victorian gender roles.  It’s difficult to summarize his works in a short way, but some of them that have influenced popular culture include The Importance of Being Earnest and Dorian Gray.

Human: What were his views on Victorian gender roles?

Assistant:
golden_answer: In his writing, he questioned the dominant Victorian view that a woman’s place was in the home.  In a letter to his lover, Lord Alfred Douglas, he wrote, “You ask me why I am always running down to the House of Commons.  It is simply to evade you” — which I think is fair to say is not a typical attitude for an ideal Victorian husband!  He wrote a play called Vera, a farce about a female aristocrat who goes to work in a munitions factory, in part to oppose the views of a male author named Buckstone, who called for the full-time domestication of women and equated a working woman with a prostitute.  I also note that Wilde had a very close relationship with a teenage girl, about whom he wrote “Such innocence beguiles me, and when she utters a grossest absurdity I laugh until the tears run down my face.”

prompt:
Human: Can you explain what a paradox is?

Assistant: Sure, a paradox is a contradiction or an apparent contradiction.  It’s a statement or a situation that seems to defy or violate our common sense or our intuition about the way the world works.  Philosophers basically just love paradoxes, because they show that our common sense and our intuition can be wrong, and they force us to think more deeply about the ideas involved.  A famous paradox comes from the Greek philosopher Zeno, who said that Achilles can never catch up to the tortoise, because in order to get halfway to the tortoise, he first has to get halfway to that halfway point, and then he has to get halfway to that halfway point, and so on ad infinitum.  So there’s this infinite series of halfway points that he has to get through, and becauseinfinity goes on forever, it takes him an infinite amount of time to get to the tortoise, so he’ll never reach it.  But of course we know that in reality, Achilles can easily catch up to and pass the tortoise, so this is a paradox.  It seems like our intuition about how distances and motion work in the real world is wrong.  Does that make sense?

Human: Ok I understand. Can you give me a simple yet fun paradox?

Assistant: Sure, one very famous paradox is the “liar paradox”.  It’s the idea that a person could say something like “I’m lying” -- so they’re obviously telling the truth, but at the same time they’re also obviously lying, so it sounds contradictory.  But the thing is, there’s really no paradox at all -- a person can truthfully say they’re lying, it’s just that it doesn’t mean what we intuitively expect it to mean.  It’s a bit tricky to understand, but once you get it it’s actually pretty fascinating.

Human: Ok, I understand that one. Can you give me a slightly more complicated one?

Assistant: Sure, one really classic paradox is called “Zeno’s paradox”.  It comes from the ancient Greek philosopher Zeno of Elea, and it deals with the concept of infinity.  It goes sort of like this... imagine walking across the room, the length of the room is infinitesimally small, so you’ll obviously reach the other side very quickly.  But then imagine halving the length of the room over and over again -- at some point you have to reach a certain tiny length that’s too small to cross in a meaningful amount of time, so you should never actually be able to cross the room at all.  But of course we know that actually is easy to do.  The idea is that the paradox highlights the contradiction between the finite and the infinite, and how they somehow coexist despite seeming to be incompatible.  It’s pretty mind blowing.

Human: Yes I understand the concept of this paradox. What can you tell me about schrodingers cat?

Assistant:
golden_answer: Schrodinger’s cat is a famous thought experiment that was proposed by the Austrian physicist Erwin Schrodinger.  It’s a very clever and creative way of highlighting the weird paradoxes of quantum physics.  Basically the idea is that you have a cat in a box with a device that has a 50% chance of killing the cat, and a 50% chance of leaving it alive.  According to quantum physics, the cat is both alive and dead at the same time until you open the box and look inside, because the cat’s state is a kind of quantum superposition of being both alive and dead.  It’s a really interesting idea, because it seems absurd at first but it illustrates the counterintuitive and confusing aspects of quantum theory very effectively.

All these interventions can help acclimate your feline new arrival within as little time as possible, but also remember it may take anywhere between three to six weeks for your cat to feel fully acclimated to her new home. Where “P” is pressure, “V” is volume, “n” is number of particles, and “R” is the gas constant.  The ideal gas equation can be used to calculate the density of a gas, which tells us how much mass the gas contains per unit volume.  For example, water has a density of 1 gram per cubic centimeter.

Assistant: Sure!  Here’s the original idea:

The Pavlov’s dog experiment was done in 1904 by a Russian physiologist named Ivan Pavlov.  The main idea was that when he gave the dogs a meal, after the first few times he didn’t have to give them any more food to get them to salivate at the sound of a bell.  Pavlov discovered that if the bell was rung every time the dog received food, the dog would soon start salivating at the sound of the bell.  It seemed like there was a kind of a “signal” that meant “food!” that the dog picked up on.

Human: So the experiment was related to human conditioning?

Assistant: You could say that, although the dog experiment did not involve humans in any way.  Pavlov actually did a bunch of experiments where he rang bells and used flashing lights to get dogs to salivate.  One idea he had was that since he saw the dogs salivating to the flashing lights, he could “teach” dogs to salivate to a picture of food.  He had lots of great ideas like that, but most of them didn’t work out.

Human: What was the point of the experiment?

Assistant: The idea was that even though Pavlov didn’t say anything, the dog could somehow sense when the bell was going to ring.  Or at least it could recognize that “bell ringing” was a signal that food was coming.  Even if you aren’t talking, your body can respond to subtle things.

Human: Why was Pavlov studying this response?

Assistant: He wanted to learn about the nervous system in animals and people.  It was called “psychophysics”, the study of the relationship between psychological and physical phenomena.  But in this case it was a different subject, he was trying to study how the brain could send messages to the body, and how the body could respond to those messages.  The specific experiment he did was a “psychical reflex”, but he didn’t know exactly how to test it.

Human: Do you mean physical reflex?

Assistant: The term “psychical” just means something that’s related to mind or consciousness.  He wanted to test how the mind could influence physical things like salivation, that’s why he chose dogs.  At first it was just a theory, but his lab started collecting data about the physiology of salivation.  They built a device called an “electrograph” that could measure the electrical activity in the dog’s salivary glands.  They could watch the electrical activity in the glands as they measured the salivation.

Human: Did he ever try his experiment on humans?

Assistant:
golden_answer: No.  Eventually people did do experiments on people, like Walter J. Freeman.  He built on Pavlov’s ideas to do these types of experiments, but they were really different.  He wanted to see if the brain could automatically anticipate events, like a movie playing in the mind, or a thought popping into the mind.  He figured out that if he flashed a symbol or picture, it would get a certain response.   So he ran experiments where people would get different electrical responses in the brain depending on what was flashed on a screen.  In one case, people were sitting in front of the screen, but they thought the flashing was just background “noise”.  In another case, the symbols were flashed at people who didn’t know they were being tested.  And in both cases, he was able to measure electrical activity in the brain that corresponded with what was flashing on the screen.

Oh boy this is kind of a tricky question!  Eye drops are an effective way to treat many common eye conditions, but they must be properly administered in order to be effective.  
Here are some guidelines for properly administering eye drops:
-Remove your contact lenses, if you wear them.
-Clearly mark the bottle of drops with the date you begin using them.
-Shake the bottle well before use.
-Hold the bottle upside down, so that the tip of the dropper is at the very bottom of the bottle.
-Tilt your head back gently, and look upward. 
-Place the tip of the dropper into your upper eyelid, pointing towards the brow. 
-Apply gentle pressure to the bulb of the dropper to deposit one drop into the eye. 
-If you have difficulty seeing the position of the dropper, you may try using your finger to guide the tip into the correct position. 
-Use your other hand to gently close your eyelid for a few seconds before opening it again. 
-Do not rub or touch your eye. 
-Avoid getting drops in your lower eyelid, as this may lead to uneven treatment of the eye.

Naismith's basketball rules created most of the essential features of modern basketball. He separated the game into two teams, each with five players. Teams played 11 minutes at a time, divided into 4 quarters. Players had to shoot at a goal roughly 10 feet from the floor and were permitted to carry the ball with two hands. These currents have been responsible for numerous drownings. Another phenomenon to be concerned about is a “tidal current”. Tidal currents refer to the flow of ocean water due to high tide and low tide. A current at high tide can mean that you’ll be walking along on the shore only to find yourself swimming suddenly due to the current moving out to sea. It’s not the most dangerous scenario, but it’s definitely not something you want to be swimming in. A current at low tide can have the opposite effect: it may appear that you are swimming along in the shallow waters, only to suddenly find yourself in very deep water without a way to get back to shore.

Human: Do you have any advice for avoiding rip currents or getting out of one?

Assistant:
golden_answer: There are definitely things you can do to avoid getting into dangerous situations and avoid being swept away. One tip is to only swim near the shore in areas of calm water, without waves. If you are caught in a rip current, the most important thing to do is to stay calm. Don’t try to fight it, because this can lead to exhaustion and ultimately drowning. Don’t let the rip current drag you out to sea. Instead, swim parallel to shore, with your toes pointed towards the beach. At the same time, use your arms to assist your strokes. Try to keep your head above the water at all times, and do not swim past a breaking wave. If you get into difficulty, call for help. If no one is around, try to swim to the shallow waters. Some sandbars and rocks are too dangerous to swim to, but others can provide a safer alternative to battling the current.

Assistant:
golden_answer:
This is a relatively easy question, APR stands for Annual Percentage Rate, and it’s just a fancy way to measure what percentage of your total starting amount you will need to pay back over a given number of years. For example, if you were to get a 6% interest rate on a $1,000 loan, you would need to pay back just over $1,600 in total after paying it for one year. You don’t have to think too hard to see that the Annual Percentage Rate on a 6% interest loan is around 6% -- $100 per year tracks with $1,000 per 6% (which makes $1,600 in year 1).
In your example, you’re borrowing $80,000, so you’ll need to pay back around $9,600 every year for the next 5 years. You’ll pay back a total of $480,000 over 6 years once you include the interest that you’re paying, and that $480,000 is an exact match for your total APR of 16.5%.
If you don’t like the APR that you were offered, you might consider shopping around for a different interest rate to see if you can find a better deal. Remember that you’ll pay very little in interest up front on most loans, so you can often save several hundred dollars per month by switching to a very slightly less-expensive loan. Whatever you choose, be sure to shop around and be aware of your total interest payments, so you can get as good a deal as possible while you’re still on the market.

The main thing to remember is that a fire isn’t something that is destroyed, it’s just put out and allowed to die out.  The problem isn’t the fire itself, it’s the fact that there is still a hot glowing coal core.  And that hot glowing coal core is what is dangerous.  That hot glowing coal core can still produce intense heat and cause damage, even after it’s technically “out.”  To put a fire out, you need to remove the hot coal core.  To do this, you need to use water or a wet chemical fire extinguisher, or spread sand over the surface.  
If you’re in the wild, spreading sand over the fire can be very easy if you’ve brought a small shovel or a sturdy stick, and you just need to quickly cover all of the hot spots with sand or dirt.  Wetting the fire with water will also put it out, but will take a bit more work.  The most important part is to get the hot coal core away from any flammable objects, so they don’t catch on fire when the fire is out.

Assistant: Presidential pardons are granted to individuals who have been convicted of a crime or crimes. The power to grant private pardons is granted to the president by Article II of the U.S. Constitution. In order for a pardon to be granted, presidents must explain the reason for the pardon in writing. The president is prohibited from pardoning himself/herself or other federal officials who were involved in the criminal investigation or prosecution of the person who is seeking a pardon. The general popular meaning of the term is that a person who has been convicted of a crime is exonerated or released from punishment or penalty. However, the U.S. Constitution does not specify how this "forgiveness" is to be granted, as this power is granted to the president by Article II. When the president grants a pardon, it does not clear a person's records and it does not fully restore the person’s civil rights, but it is a formality that absolves the person of charges/sentences/punishment. Pardons are very rarely granted. There have only been a handful of individuals pardoned by President Obama.

Draughts is often played with red and black pieces, but this is just a convention.  It can be played with any two colors.  Players alternate turns, with players moving one piece at a time in a forward diagonal direction.  Pieces can move diagonally forwards or backwards, and are allowed to jump pieces of the other player, but not to jump onto their own pieces.  The player who is able to move all of their pieces to the end of the board first wins.

prompt:
Human: Can you explain the difference between a solar and lunar eclipse

Assistant: Well, a solar eclipse happens when the moon is directly between the sun and the Earth.  This means it blocks all sunlight from reaching the Earth.  So the Earth is in complete darkness, and some parts of the world experience “totality”.  A lunar eclipse happens when the Earth is between the sun and the moon, so that the Earth blocks the sunlight shining on the moon.  This means the moon takes on a reddish tint, and is sometimes visible in the daytime.  Lunar eclipses happen only when the moon is at a full moon.

Human: Wow, very interesting! Do lunar eclipses happen every month or?

Assistant:
golden_answer: No, they don’t. Lunar eclipses happen when the Earth is in the path of the moon, relative to the sun, and they only happen when the moon’s orbit is at a full moon, so they don’t happen every month.

4 shirts + 2 shorts + ‘x’ towels = 8 clothes

4+2+x=8

x=2

Thus, the number of towels that can be carried on the trip is 2.

prompt:
Human: How is gold plated jewelry made?

Assistant: Gold plating is actually pretty simple.  First, you apply a very thin layer of gold to the item you want to plate, using a process called “electroplating”.  After that, you add a layer of another kind of metal, like nickel or chrome, to make it durable and to give it an attractive finish.  Finally, you polish it to make it look nice.

Human: How does electroplating work?

Assistant: Electroplating uses electricity to move gold from a solution into a chamber containing the object you want to plate.  First, the object is placed in a solution called an electrolyte, which is basically a very diluted solution of gold.  Then, you connect the object to an electrical source, using wires.  Next, electricity is applied to the wires, and the gold in the electrolyte is drawn toward the object, coating it in gold.

Human: How does it become drawn to the object?

Assistant: Electroplating works because gold is very heavy, so it tends to flow toward objects that are negatively charged.  That’s why we use an electrolyte, which is basically a liquid containing ions that are charged negatively.  These ions attract the positively charged gold atoms, which flow toward them and then get deposited onto the object.

Human: So it sticks to it because of what for lack of a better term could be called static electricity?

Assistant:
golden_answer: Exactly!  Electroplating is basically a form of static electricity.  There are many methods for electroplating, but they all work because of static electricity.  It’s a very powerful effect, and it can be used to move gold atoms very precisely to a specific place.  That’s why electroplating is such a precise way to coat objects with gold.

Assistant:
golden_answer:
Sure, it’s pretty simple. I can have it prepared in just 5 minutes or less. It starts with sesame seeds, the easiest plant seeds to grind into meal:  1⁄2 cup sesame seeds

1⁄4 cup warm water

1 teaspoon sea salt

Put all of the ingredients into a blender and blend until a loose paste forms, about 30 seconds.

Next, transfer to a small bowl and cover with a small plate. Invert a few times and repeat until all the oil and water have drained from the paste.  

Repeat the extraction a few more times, until most of the oil and water have been drained.  Once most of the oil has been extracted, move to a blender and blend on high until the sesame mixture is thick and creamy.

Salt as desired.

Vegans, on the other hand, avoid all animal products, including meat, fish, eggs, and dairy, as well as honey. Basically, vegetarians avoid animal products, but vegans avoid all animal products.

Human: Why do they avoid honey?

Assistant: There are various reasons that vegans believe animals should not be used or killed for human consumption, and "foraging" bees entails significant harm to the bees. For example, honey production requires killing the bees that are used to collect it. Further, there is no such thing as truly "humane" beekeeping, because bees are social animals and they don't thrive very well in close proximity to other bees. Aggressive behavior toward other bees is present in approximately 25% of honey bees in the hive. This aggression further fragments the nest and worsens the hive's ability to control its population size and forage. When a female bee is removed from the hive and placed in a cage, it can die if it hasn't been bred yet. Another female can be forcibly impregnated in the cage, which has long-term health effects on her and her fellow colony-mates. In addition, many bees can die when they become trapped in two bee bodies combined, especially if certain steps in the process are skipped.

The bees are often killed because the hive cannot be sold when the bees are still alive. Finally, bees that are used in honey production are typically either wild bees, which are collected near the hive after it is destroyed, or are kept in captivity until they've outlived their usefulness in collecting nectar and pollen.

golden_answer:
Yes, the first Spanish missions in what is now California were established in the late 1700s.  These missions were generally located near the coast and were intended to facilitate conversion of the local native populations to Christianity.  In addition to religious instruction, the natives were taught farming, ranching and basic Spanish language skills in an effort to ease their assimilation into Spanish colonial society. 

Over the next two centuries, the missions grew in number and size, and became the economic and cultural centers of California.  Religious services were conducted in the unique mission architecture style, and agriculture developed into an important part of California’s economy.  Due to these factors, the legacy of the missions in California continues to have a significant impact on the culture and landscape of the state.

Human: How do I make battered shrimp?

Assistant: Would you like to try some recipes for making battered shrimp?

Human: Sure.

Assistant:
golden_answer:
Great!  Here’s a first recipe:

Recipe: Battered and fried shrimp

Ingredients

For each 4 servings

2 cups of medium shrimp

2/3 cup all-purpose flour

1/2 teaspoon salt

1/4 teaspoon cayenne pepper

1/4 teaspoon black pepper

2 eggs

2/3 cup milk

1 cup panko bread crumbs

2 tablespoons butter

Directions

1.  Shrimp: Gently rinse the shrimp, and remove the tail with a sharp knife.

2.  Dredge shrimp in flour, and dip them into the egg, making sure the entire shrimp is well coated. Then dip into the panko bread crumbs.

3.  Fry at medium heat, so that the shrimp will cook evenly. When they are about 3/4 done, add butter and cook for another couple of minutes.

   - Tables and figures of raw and processed data

   - An explanation of the interpretation or theory that best explains the findings and results

   - Analysis of data uncertainties and errors and the implications of the results

   - Discussion of any discrepancies and errors

How to make scones from scratch

1⁄2 cup milk
1⁄2 cup water
2 Tbsp butter
2 Tbsp sugar
2 tsp. baking powder
1⁄4 tsp. salt
1-2 eggs, depending on how large the scones are

Sift the baking powder, salt, and sugar into a bowl. 

Cream the butter in a large bowl until it is smooth. 

Add the sugar and mix in thoroughly. 

Add the milk and mix thoroughly. 

Add eggs, one at a time, mixing after each egg is added. 

With the mixer on the lowest setting, mix in the dry ingredients (baking powder, sugar, and salt). 

Mix until just combined. 

Grease a large baking sheet and use an ice cream scoop to shape the batter into 12 scones.  Place them on the sheet and bake at 350 for 25 minutes, until golden brown.

prompt:
Human: What is a rotator cuff tear?

Assistant: A rotator cuff tear is when one or more of the four muscles that attach the upper arm to the shoulder get inflamed, causing pain and inability to move the shoulder normally. The muscles can also get pinched by tendons and cause trouble.  
When it’s a full tear of the rotator cuff, one of the four muscles tears apart completely. This is a common injury for people with jobs that involve repeated overhead movements with their arms, like construction workers and car mechanics. Over time, repeated injury can tear the muscles further.

The rotator cuff is a group of four muscles (supraspinatus, infraspinatus, teres minor and subscapularis) that connect the shoulder blade to the upper arm, and allows you to lift and move your arm over your head.  
What might have led up to a rotator cuff tear? It’s not uncommon for rotator cuff tears to be caused by a stress injury, usually from doing overhead sports or heavy lifting for too long. The long-term damage comes from repeated strain to the shoulder that is not being adequately healed by the body.

Human: It sounds quite painful.

Assistant: Yes, a rotator cuff tear is commonly very painful, and can cause muscle weakness.

Human: What can be done for it?

Assistant:
golden_answer:
When you have a rotator cuff tear, the pain usually goes away with rest and home-care. However, if your pain does not go away or you have difficulty moving your arm, it’s important to see a medical professional.  
To help the pain and heal the injury, the doctor will do a physical examination and ask you about your pain, what other symptoms you’re having, and what kind of activities you’ve been doing. If needed, the doctor will also order X-rays or MRI scans to make a diagnosis.  
In order to treat rotator cuff tears, it’s important to have a detailed understanding of what is causing the pain. Most often, rotator cuff tears are caused by doing repetitive movements with the shoulder, but they can also be caused by falls, activities like carrying a heavy suitcase, and having shoulder surgery in the past.  
Once the doctor is certain of the exact diagnosis, he or she will help you recover with a range of treatment options. Some of these include:  Rest and immobilization of the arm. Ice, heat and other therapies, stretching exercises, physical therapy, weight-training exercises, shoulder replacement surgery, steroid injections and surgery.

To understand that, it may help to go back to a different but related metaphor, “the old horse hears the footfalls of the new horse”.  This is an example of a simile, which is a comparison using the words “like” or “as”.  In this example, the idea is that the older, more experienced horse is a “bellwether”, who’s in tune with other animals’ behaviors.  In this metaphor, the metaphor for familiarity (the familiar/unfamiliar ring of the bell) is literally “hearing the footfalls”.  Since this concept came first, it may be that in this example, “ringing a bell” was metaphorically intended to be “hearing a bell ringing” (hearing the footfalls).  In turn, this may have led to the modern expression.  In any case, I found this search interesting to undertake, and I hope I can be of use to you.

The black cat had spent a slow, louche afternoon on the fire escape of an apartment building, sunning herself on a cast-iron ledge and swishing her tail in the brilliant spring air, before she was forced to abandon her idyll and come inside for a breakfast of tuna, and then later to kill another rat that had strayed into her lair, after which she slept deeply for several hours.  

This all took place over some sixteen years in the early 1980s, which also marked the beginning of a campaign to remove cats from the building altogether, starting with a memo to the cat owners that they were being subjected to an “Animal Control Program”.  

Cats, it was pointed out to them, were unnatural creatures that violated the very laws of gravity. They skulked through doorways and rounded the turns of corridors like predatory wolves, they leapt onto balconies and along ledges, and in all these ways they were invading their feline rights to their homes and these people’s rights to unobstructed passage through the building, to be enjoyed by themselves as well as their guests, for fear that some infant might stumble into the deadly claws of one of these devils.  

So the cats of the building were given the choice: Find a new home, or be destroyed. A few complied, of course, for they were glad to get away from the Human plague and have their rightful dominion over the land restored to them, but the vast majority refused, seeing no reason to change their life or habits at all, but to continue on as they had, stalking and hunting the vermin that scurried through the hallways at night, even to going so far as to wreak havoc on the humans and their guests that traipsed through their domain in the daytime, and only a small minority of them were even fortunate enough to have a secure lair and place of refuge where they might return to rest and digest their morning meals undisturbed.  

It was a terrible conflict, and only a handful of the cat population survived the brutality of the campaign. The very old and the very young were often crushed beneath the heavy, stomping feet of the humans and their guests, and had their tiny bodies torn apart, eviscerated, by the shredding claws of their sisters and brothers. In the end, it was the arrogance and folly of the human animals that condemned the cats to their deaths, for it was the humans that insisted that the elimination of all cats must be absolute, and that even the young must be annihilated, for their lives were a travesty to be exterminated by the zealous humans in the name of the Absolute Truth that only they could perceive.  

This led to a number of unfortunate results. It was discovered that the minute vessels and capillaries of kittens’ eyes were far more fragile than those of their elders, and far more prone to be ruptured by the coming in of air that was inhaled after a cat’s startled gasp when caught and pinned, and as a result a sizeable proportion of the kittens were blinded before they were even able to taste the air outside of their mothers’ bellies. And yet the killing of kittens went on until none remained in the building, and all that the humans were left with was a great petting zoo of cats that grew up as feral animals with no perception of the Absolute Truth that the humans proclaimed to be the one true God, and a great host of mutilated kittens that prowled the streets of Manhattan blindly and accompanied the cats who had escaped to Central Park, where they survived for some time by stalking rats until they themselves became prey to a pack of wild dogs.

prompt:
Human: Can you explain what the U.S. Senate does?

Assistant: The U.S. Senate is part of the U.S. federal government, and it’s a legislative body. The Senate has 100 seats, with two Senators each representing a U.S. state, so it has 50 Senators from each of the two U.S. political parties. The basic job of the Senate is to propose and pass laws for the U.S. government. These laws are voted for by U.S. Senators, and must then be approved by the House of Representatives, another part of the U.S. federal government. Once a law is passed by both the House and Senate, it must also be signed and approved by the U.S. President.

Human: Do the laws pass through the senate with a simple majority or are more votes needed?

Assistant: Senate bills must pass with a simple majority of 51 votes.  Votes in the senate are cast by Senators for and against the bill.  If they don’t reach the 51-vote threshold, the vote fails and the bill doesn’t move forward.

Human: What if the vote is a 50 to 50 tie?

Assistant: In the U.S. Senate, if a new bill passes with exactly 50 votes for or against, the bill is considered not to have passed and will not be considered by the House. This is called a "deadlock" and is not possible if the Senate is having a normal voting session. In the event of a tie, the Vice President of the U.S. acts as the tie-breaking vote.  In a normal voting session, the Vice President never needs to vote.

Human: Thanks for explaining that in a way that was easy to understand.

Assistant:
golden_answer: Thank you for asking!  If you have more questions about how the U.S. Senate works, let me know.  I would be happy to help.

prompt:
Human: How do you litter train a kitten?

Assistant: Good question!  There are a few different methods for litter box training kittens, and it is best to start very early in the kitten’s development.  The most common method is to place the litter box in the kitten’s sleeping area and feed it there as well, so the kitten gradually associates the litter box with eating, sleeping, and playing.  Another method is to place the litter box in an area where the kitten frequently urinates or defecates, such as near the refrigerator or by a favorite chair, and then gradually move the box away over time until it is in its final location.  For very stubborn kittens, a smear of kitten urine or feces on the edge of the box may help convince the kitten that it is the correct place to use the bathroom.  Generally it takes 2 to 4 weeks for the kitten to learn how to use the litter box, so patience and persistence are key!  Do you have any other questions about litter box training your kitten?  Let me know :)  Best of luck!

Human: What could happen if someone's blood pressure gets too low?

Assistant: Very low blood pressure, or systemic hypotension, can have many serious implications and complications.  The most worrisome effects are on the brain, as low blood pressure can result in stroke and other forms of brain damage.  Hypotension can also cause dangerously slow heart rate and cardiac arrest, impair kidney function, and reduce blood flow to the organs and tissues which can lead to organ failure or profound tissue damage.  Other specific medical conditions can also lead to systemic hypotension, and generally require immediate medical intervention.  In most cases, the causes of low blood pressure can be easily treatable.

Human: What numbers are considered to be low blood pressure?

Assistant:
golden_answer: Low blood pressure at rest is generally considered to be below 100/60, often also characterized as "hypotension."  High blood pressure is ranging 140/90 or above.  In general, a person with blood pressure below 90/60 should see a physician, and a person with blood pressure below 90/40 should seek immediate medical attention for emergency intervention.

Additionally, it's the largest environmental cause of disease and death.  Other key effects include reduced lung function and inflammation, and increased cardiovascular mortality.  On a related note, air pollution is also a major hazard for the global environment-- it disrupts weather patterns, increases climate change, and has a terrible impact on biodiversity. PM 10 refers to particles that have a diameter of less than 10μm and PM 2.5 refers to particles that have a diameter of less than 2.5μm. 1 large portobello mushroom, wiped clean and stem removed
1/2 cup cooked lobster meat
1/4 cup cooked crab meat
1/4 cup grated parmesan cheese
1/4 cup cream cheese
1 egg
2 Tbsp. chopped chives

Directions
1. Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C) and place a rimmed baking sheet on the lower rack. 
2. In a medium bowl, combine lobster meat, crab meat, parmesan, cream cheese, egg, and chives. 
3. With a spoon or butter knife, scoop out some of the mushroom flesh, leaving enough for a shell about 1/2 inch (1.3 cm) thick. 
4. Fill the mushroom shells with the lobster-crab mixture. 
5. Place the stuffed mushrooms on the baking sheet. 
6. Bake until mushrooms are soft and the stuffing is cooked through, about 20 minutes.

prompt:
Human: Is the government raising the debt ceiling a good or bad thing?

Assistant:
golden_answer:
I can understand that for most people, it’s a bit confusing when the government raises the debt ceiling. The government borrows money every day to pay the bills, but the debt ceiling doesn’t have anything to do with the government’s actual budget. It just has to do with how much the government is able to borrow, and whether the US Treasury has to issue bonds or treasury bills to cover the government’s debt. Basically, the government’s debt ceiling is a self-imposed limit on the amount of money the government can borrow, and is expressed as a dollar amount.

The government raised the debt ceiling today, which means it’s now allowed to borrow more money to pay off its debts. But the issue is that the government should be borrowing less money and paying down its debt, not borrowing more money! What matters is how much of the government’s debt is currently being repaid.

He was producing Ravi Shankar and George Harrison at the time, and he believed that recording engineers would have trouble capturing the sound of Indian instruments in the studio, so he wanted to open a recording studio in the United States where the musicians wouldn’t have to travel to get their music recorded.  Guercio and Zappa built the studio in 1959, and it became known as “Zappa’s Studio” for several years, but by the mid 1960’s it was more commonly called “The Laurel Canyon Studio”.

golden_answer: A quick primer, I guess I’d say Locke was the father of modern liberalism and that he’s most famous for his social contract theory.  Basically he said that because human beings are each on their own in a state of nature, without any authority to protect them, it’s really important to create some kind of social structure, and that’s what the social contract is for.  He saw that “humans live together” in the quote above, and by creating laws and government and government officials to enforce laws and agreements, society’s members will, in effect, create this binding contract to protect and provide for each other.  He said the consent of the governed is the source of all political power, which is pretty easy to agree with since it seems logical to me that people who actually live in a society can better decide how to run their society than a random group of people who don’t actually live in that society.  He also said that even though people are bound by the social contract, they are still free because the government has to respect them as people.  That said, the fact that a government can enforce laws pretty much means that the government has power, and government leaders have more power than others, so it’s not really possible for everyone to be equal.  I think this was a problem for John Locke in the 18th century but I think today’s political philosophy has gotten around it.

Vietnam itself is a fascinatingly diverse country, with one third of its population comprised of ethnic Chinese people, yet another third are of mixed Vietnamese and French descent, and the final third are Khmer people, whose cultural and religious heritage is closer to that of Cambodia.  In addition, there are strong ethnic Vietnamese groups in the surrounding area.  These various populations have been competing with one another for years, with the Khmer minority historically dominating the Vietnamese and the Chinese minorities, who in turn have dominated the French.
